qas.question: What status did the wearing of red in medieval times represent?
On what occasion would townspeople wear red?
What root was used for red clothing owned by commoners?
Outside of sun exposure in what circumstance did pigment made from rubia tinctorum fade?

answers.text: the carminic acid in tiny female scale insects

qas.question: What trees are found only in the Mediterranean?
Where in Europe are kermes only found?
What brick color is produced by kermes?
What causes kermes dye to fade easily?

context: Red clothing was a sign of status and <a0_0>wealth<a0_0/>. It was worn not only by cardinals and princes, but also by merchants, artisans and townpeople, particularly on <a1_0>holidays<a1_0/> or special occasions. Red dye for the clothing of ordinary people was made from the roots of the <a2_0>rubia tinctorum<a2_0/>, the madder plant. This color leaned toward <b7_0>brick-red,<b7_0/> and faded easily in <b8_0>the sun or <a3_0>during washing<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The wealthy and aristocrats wore scarlet clothing dyed with kermes, or carmine, made from <a4_0>the carminic acid in tiny female scale insects<a4_0/>, which lived on the leaves of <b5_0>oak trees<b5_0/> in <b6_0>Eastern Europe<b6_0/> and around the Mediterranean. The insects were gathered, dried, crushed, and boiled with different ingredients in a long and complicated process, which produced a brilliant scarlet.
